dc:description:
The *RPGR* gene was first reported in relation to X-linked cases of retinitis pigmentosa in 1996 (Meindl *et al*., PMID: 8673101, Roepman *et al*., PMID: 8817343). Affected males with causal variants in *RPGR* have since been identified in a number of other publications, with the majority of cases showing phenotypes restricted to the eye and diagnosed with either X-linked retinitis pigmentosa 3 (PMID: 2902787, PMID: 9855162), X-linked cone-rod dystrophy 1 (PMID: 23150612, PMID: 15914600, PMID: 34800980), X-linked cone dystrophy (PMID: PMID: 33805381), or X-linked atrophic macular degeneration (PMID: 12160730). The age of onset in affected patients can range from childhood to the fourth decade of life, and presenting symptoms often include a combination of photophobia, reduced visual acuity, night blindness, electroretinogram abnormalities of both the rod and cone responses, retinal pigment epithelial abnormalities, retinal arteriolar constriction, and/or peripheral visual field loss. A small subset of cases exhibit a syndromic presentation in which retinal degeneration is accompanied by ciliary abnormalities leading to recurrent respiratory infections and hearing impairment. These cases can be diagnosed with X-linked retinitis pigmentosa and sinorespiratory infections, with or without deafness (PMID: 10094550, PMID: 12920075), or may be separately diagnosed with X-linked retinitis pigmentosa and primary ciliary dyskinesia (PMID: 16055928). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping & Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism (loss of function in the RPGR gene product) and mode of inheritance (X-linked, with female carriers ranging from unaffected to moderately or severely affected) to be consistent among unrelated patients diagnosed with either X-linked retinitis pigmentosa 3, X-linked cone-rod dystrophy 1, X-linked atrophic macular degeneration, or X-linked retinitis pigmentosa and sinorespiratory infections, with or without deafness. Despite the low intra-familiar and high inter-familiar variability in clinical features, the phenotypic variability between these diagnoses appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, these cases have been lumped into a single disease entity, referred to as *RPGR*-related retinopathy (MONDO:0100437).

Thirteen suspected deleterious variants in *RPGR* were scored as part of this curation (three missense, one frameshift, six nonsense, one stop-loss, and two affecting splicing), which have been collectively reported in thirteen probands in nine publications (PMID: 8673101, PMID: 16055928, PMID: 33805381, PMID: 9855162, PMID: 12160730, PMID: 34800980, PMID: 12920075, PMID: 15914600, PMID: 10094550). All probands were males and were hemizygous for the variant of interest. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function in the predominant retinal isoform of *RPGR*, characterized in some cases by nonsense, frameshift, or splicing variants predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay of all *RPGR* isoforms, which is associated with additional extraocular phenotypes (PMID: 10094550, PMID: 12920075), PMID: 16055928). One large family with co-segregation of the genotype and phenotype among affected members was scored as part of this curation, (PMID: 2902787), while other segregation evidence was not included in this curation as the maximum scoring for this evidence type had already been reached.

This gene-disease association is also supported by biochemical evidence that the RPGR protein localizes to the connecting cilia of rod and cone photoreceptors in the retina, and to the transitional zone of the motile cilia in the respiratory tract (PMID: 12766038). This indicates a possible role in regulating cytoskeletal organization and ciliary assembly. RPGR forms complexes with the ciliary proteins CEP290 (PMID: 16632484), RPGRIP1L (PMID: 33808286), and IQCB1 (PMID: 15723066), all of which are encoded by genes that harbor variants associated with inherited retinal disease. *RPGR* silencing in retinal pigment epithelium cells triggers shortening of the primary cilia (PMID: 20631154). Murine and canine models of *RPGR* loss-of-function recapitulate the inheritance pattern and retinal features of the human patients (PMID: 10725384, PMID: 11978759), while a zebrafish loss-of-function model recapitulates the ciliary defects (PMID: 19815619). The phenotypes of these models can be rescued by therapeutic administration of a human *RPGR* transgene (PMID: 28549772), but not by patient-associated *RPGR* variants (PMID: 19815619).

In summary, *RPGR* is definitively associated with *RPGR*-related retinopathy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence, leading to a definitive classification. This classification has been approved by the ClinGen Retina GCEP on August 4th, 2022 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: Despite the strong evidence that the functions of RPGR that are mediated by protein-protein interaction are disrupted by this variant, only moderate up-scoring has been performed as the genotyping was by candidate gene sequencing rather than a genome-wide method.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.644G>T (p.Gly215Val) is a missense variant in exon 7 of 15 and has been shown to disrupt the ability of the protein product to interact with PDE6D, INPP5E, and RPGRIP1L (PMID: 30622176, Figure 4).

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.469+1G>T is a canonical splice site variant in the final exon (exon 15) that disrupts the 5' splice site of intron 5. Down-scoring has been performed since functional evidence confirming the expected effect on splicing is not available.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.2847_2848inv (p.Glu949_Glu950delinsAspTer) is an indel in the final exon (exon 15) that introduces a premature stop codon. Although it is not predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay, it at least disrupts ~18% of the C-terminus of the protein product. Moderate down-scoring has been performed due to the genotyping method.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.2383G>T (p.Glu795Ter) is a nonsense variant in the final exon (exon 15) that is not predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay but truncates ~31% of the C-terminus of the protein product.
In HEK-293T cells, truncation was confirmed by western blotting (Figure 3b), yet immunocytochemistry showed normal (cytoplasmic) localization (Figure 3c).

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.581G>A (p.Trp194Ter) is a nonsense variant predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay or to at least disrupt the C-terminal 76% of the protein product. The variant was slightly down-scored due to having been genotyped by candidate gene sequencing rather than genome-wide methods.
NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.294C>A (p.His98Gln) is a missense variant and does not have associated evidence of impact on RPGR function.

The variant has been moderately up-scored since NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.3457T>A (p.Ter1153Lys) is a stop-loss variant that triggers an extension of the C-terminus of RPGR by 38 amino acids. It is not predicted to undergo nonsense-mediated decay, but its inheritance pattern with largely unaffected female carriers is consistent with loss-of-function.
NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.154G>T (p.Gly52Ter) is a nonsense variant predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay or to at least disrupt the C-terminal 94% of the protein product.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.789_790del (p.Thr265fs) is a frameshift variant in exon 8 of exon 15 that is predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay or at least to disrupt ~68% of the C-terminus of the protein product. Moderate down-scoring was performed due to the candidate gene-based genotyping method.

The variant has been up-scored due to mRNA-level evidence confirming that it disrupts splicing in a way predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay, but slightly down-scored due to the absence of confirmation of a null effect at the protein level.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.572_619+9del is a deletion variant spanning the function between exon 6 and intron 6. It has been shown to yield a shorter mRNA generated by the use of a cryptic splice donor site in exon 6 (Figure 4) that is predicted to trigger a frameshift and nonsense-mediated decay or disruption of the C-terminal 84% of the protein product.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.179G>T (p.Gly60Val) is a missense variant in exon 3 that has not been functionally characterized to confirm an impact on the gene product. Although it is absent from gnomAD, it has been observed in multiple apparently unrelated families in this study (PMID: 9855162) and in one other study by the same group (PMID: 9399904). It may be a founder variant present within the population of the U.K.

NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.2929G>T (p.Gly977Ter) is a nonsense variant in the final exon (exon 15) that is not predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay, but disrupts ~15% of the C-terminus of the protein product. Moderate down-scoring has been performed to account for the limited genotyping method.
The published LOD score has been included rather than the estimated LOD score because the published one was calculated from this family and three others.
evidence.rdfs:label: Musarella_1988_Family_13
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Affected family members have been diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa, with an X-linked pattern of inheritance, with some affected males showing a milder form of disease relative to other pedigrees. The tapetal reflex with metallic sheen was observed in the fundus of female carriers, along with RPE atrophy and pigmentary migration to the inner layers of the retina.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001034853.2(RPGR):c.2917G>T (p.Glu973Ter) is a nonsense variant in the final exon (exon 15) that is not predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay but truncates ~16% of the C-terminus of the protein product. The variant has  been up-scored for predicted disruption of the protein product, but moderately down-scored for the patient having been genotyped by X-chromosome-focused methods only.

This model exhibits ocular phenotypes and underlying rod and cone photoreceptor dysfunction that approximately match those of the human patients. Down-scoring has been performed due to the relatively slow development of mouse phenotypes given the accelerated nature of the human disease course and for the lack of observed or characterized respiratory phenotypes.

The model has been well-characterized at the ocular level and triggers molecular and photoreceptor cell defects (Figures 4a, 4b, 5, 6, 7a, and 7b) that are consistent with human patient features such as night blindness, central visual field loss, and peripheral visual field loss. The model matches the human mode of inheritance as well. Respiratory / extraocular phenotypes in the model have not been observed or characterized to the same extent.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse knockout model of Rpgr loss-of-function

evidence.dc:description: The zebrafish model does not match the human retinal phenotypes but exhibits ciliary defects and convincingly argues for a role of RPGR in ciliary morphology and function.

The model matches the human patients in that the morpholino-treated animals exhibit ciliary defects (in ciliary length but not ciliary number at Kupffer's vesicle in Figures 2D and 2E). Other phenotypes such as shortened body axis, kinked tail, and hydrocephaly are known to be characteristic of other zebrafish models of ciliary defects. On the other hand, the development of retinal morphology appears to occur normally (Figure S2).
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish model with morpholino-based disruption of rpgr

evidence.dc:description: The models study naturally occurring variants that do not have equivalent / orthologous variants reported in human patients but recapitulate both histological and functional features of the human disease. Down-scoring has been performed to acknowledge some overlap with the findings of an already-scored mouse model (PMID: 10725384).

The two models have been well-characterized at the ocular level and exhibit ERG abnormalities (Fig. 4IB1-3) and degeneration of visual cells and outer segment disorganization, leading to end-stage retinal disease (Fig.4IIE-4IIH). These phenotypes are consistent with human patient features such as night blindness, central visual field loss, and peripheral visual field loss.
evidence.rdfs:label: Two dog models of Rpgr loss-of-function

evidence.dc:description: The experiment shows convincing rescue in two mouse models, but has been down-scored for the absence of unaffected control animals for comparison, and for the absence of information on the rescue of other phenotypes from these models at the microscopic level.
ERG analyses show significant rescue of rod function and a rescue of cone function that is trending towards statistical significance (Figures 5B and 5C).
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of Rpgr-deficient mice with human RPGR

evidence.dc:description: The wild-type human RPGR allele meaningfully rescues the defects of the rpgr knockdown animals, while one of the missense variants and most of the predicted null variants do not. This confirms the compatibility of the animal model with the human disease mechanism.

Injection of the wild-type (human) RPGR allele fully rescues the defects of the rpgr knockdown animals (Figures 3B and 3C). Injection of mRNA encoding human variants caused varying degrees of rescue of embryonic defects, from low (p.T99N, p.E589X, p.L280X, p.K190X, p.T124X) to near-wild-type (p.G173R, p.G165V, p.G60V, p.E1071X, p.E853X), (Figure 4).
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of zebrafish rpgr mutant

evidence.dc:description: The finding is consistent with a role for RPGR in the assembly of the primary cilium.
Cells transfected with RPGR-targeting shRNA exhibited significant shortening of the primary cilia, consistent with a role in the assembly of the primary cilium (Figures 4B-4D).
evidence.rdfs:label: shRNA-based knockdown of RPGR in an RPE cell line

evidence.dc:description: Despite the tissue-specificity and reproducibility of this localization evidence across multiple studies, it has been scored only at the default level because the specific functional contribution of RPGR to the organization or transport processes in the retinal or respiratory cilia is not yet well understood.

This identification of RPGR as a potential regulator of ciliary organization and/or transport in multiple tissues is consistent with the diverse phenotypes associated with RPGR loss-of-function, ranging from visual defects associated with rod and cone dysfunction to respiratory defects associated with dysfunction of the respiratory motile cilia.
evidence.rdfs:label: RPGR localization to photoreceptor connecting cilia

evidence.dc:description: This physical interaction has been scored because of the similarity between the disease entities associated with each gene, and because of the implications for the role of both proteins in ciliary transport. This evidence has been up-scored because RPGR also similarly interacts with RPGRIP1L (PMID: 33808286) and IQCB1 (PMID: 15723066), both of which can cause retinitis pigmentosa in the context of broader syndromes.
The interacting gene, CEP290, is implicated in Leber congenital amaurosis 10 and multiple syndromic phenotypes (Joubert syndrome, Meckel syndrome, and Senior-Loken syndrome).
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-IP showing interaction of RPGR with CEP290
